station.longDesc: Nestled in the heart of Kaitaia is SUNSHINE 104.3 FM, a busy local radio station that serves the Far North of New Zealand and covers from north of Mangamuka to Cape Reinga, and across to Mangonui on the east coast. Sunshine FM have a friendly, professional and commercial approach to broadcasting. Since first going to air in February 1998, we have received great support from the local business community, local service clubs, emergency services and of course our listeners. The audience ranges in age from about 30 to 50 years or anyone who likes СClassic Hits from the 60Тs to todayТ. Broadcasting goes 24 hours, Monday to Sunday, with News, sport and weather provided every hour on the hour. Sunshine also promotes Maori language and customs to the wider community, and this adds a significant cultural dynamic to our product. The advertising content has a community specific focus. How can you can be involved? You are welcome to participate or send us feedback about any of our music, promotions or events. If youТre keen to be on the radio, please get in touch as weТre always looking for volunteers to be part of our vibrant team.

station.name: FLEET FM
station.longDesc: Fleet FM is a low-power non-commercial co-operative radio station which has previously broadcast permanently in Auckland and Wellington, New Zealand. It broadcast in Auckland on 88.3FM and in Wellington on 107.3FM. It was founded on 18 July 2003. The station was unique in that it is being run as a completely voluntary project and is advert free. This helps to ensure the Fleet disk jockey complete artistic control. The station's listenership crosses through traditional Auckland demographics reaching a diverse audience particularly those involved in the Arts and creative industries. Fleet has held a variety of music and art related events, such as the infamous Convoy gigs and Camp Fleet, when on New Years the radio station takes over a classic Kiwi school camp. Fleet members are often exhibiting art about town and sometimes in conjunction with the Pelvic Trust.

station.name: Te Hiku Radio
station.longDesc: Te Hiku 97.1 FM is part of the iwi communities of Te Hiku o Te Ika/the Far North, and belongs collectively to itТs five iwi. Te Hiku FM and was born out of the dreams and aspirations of our kuia and kaumatua (elders), as a way to retain Maori language communication within our whanau, hapu and iwi. The iwi radio format is packed with local news, interactive talkback and Waiata in Te Reo Maori. The station promotes the use of Te Reo Maori as a means of everyday communication, and whilst targeted at native speakers, listening to the station is a great way to improve Te Reo Maori for beginners, and second language learners. How do you get involved? Te Hiku FM is always keen to hear your views and encourages listeners to contribute to topical discussion. If you have a panui to share with the iwi or a kaupapa that you would like to talk about then please contact Maria Tauroa.

station.name: Atiawa Toa FM
station.longDesc: Atiawa Toa FM is one of New Zealand's premier Iwi radio stations. It's a department of Te Runanganui o Taranaki Whanui and this year celebrated its 16th birthday.
